ThingDef.label: Victini
ThingDef.description: When it shares the infinite energy it creates, that being’s entire body will be overflowing with power.\nThis Pokémon brings victory. It is said that Trainers with Victini always win, regardless of the type of encounter.

ThingDef.label: Snivy
ThingDef.description: They photosynthesize by bathing their tails in sunlight. When they are not feeling well, their tails droop.\nBeing exposed to sunlight makes its movements swifter. It uses vines more adeptly than its hands.

ThingDef.label: Servine
ThingDef.description: When it gets dirty, its leaves can’t be used in photosynthesis, so it always keeps itself clean.\nIt moves along the ground as if sliding. Its swift movements befuddle its foes, and it then attacks with a vine whip.

ThingDef.label: Serperior
ThingDef.description: It can stop its opponents’ movements with just a glare. It takes in solar energy and boosts it internally.\nIt only gives its all against strong opponents who are not fazed by the glare from Serperior’s noble eyes.

ThingDef.label: Tepig
ThingDef.description: It loves to eat roasted berries, but sometimes it gets too excited and burns them to a crisp.\nIt can deftly dodge its foe’s attacks while shooting fireballs from its nose. It roasts berries before it eats them.

ThingDef.label: Pignite
ThingDef.description: When its internal fire flares up, its movements grow sharper and faster. When in trouble, it emits smoke.\nThe more it eats, the more fuel it has to make the fire in its stomach stronger. This fills it with even more power.

ThingDef.label: Emboar
ThingDef.description: It has mastered fast and powerful fighting moves. It grows a beard of fire.\nIt can throw a fire punch by setting its fists on fire with its fiery chin. It cares deeply about its friends.

ThingDef.label: Oshawott
ThingDef.description: It fights using the scalchop on its stomach. In response to an attack, it retaliates immediately by slashing.\nThe scalchop on its stomach isn’t just used for battle—it can be used to break open hard berries as well.

ThingDef.label: Dewott
ThingDef.description: As a result of strict training, each Dewott learns different forms for using the scalchops.\nStrict training is how it learns its flowing double-scalchop technique.

ThingDef.label: Samurott
ThingDef.description: One swing of the sword incorporated in its armor can fell an opponent. A simple glare from one of them quiets everybody.\nIn the time it takes a foe to blink, it can draw and sheathe the seamitars attached to its front legs.

ThingDef.label: Patrat
ThingDef.description: Extremely cautious, one of them will always be on the lookout, but it won’t notice a foe coming from behind.\nUsing food stored in cheek pouches, they can keep watch for days. They use their tails to communicate with others.

ThingDef.label: Watchog
ThingDef.description: When they see an enemy, their tails stand high, and they spit the seeds of berries stored in their cheek pouches.\nUsing luminescent matter, it makes its eyes and body glow and stuns attacking opponents.

ThingDef.label: Lillipup
ThingDef.description: This Pokémon is far brighter than the average child, and Lillipup won’t forget the love it receives or any abuse it suffers.\nThis Pokémon is courageous but also cautious. It uses the soft fur covering its face to collect information about its surroundings.

ThingDef.label: Herdier
ThingDef.description: The black fur that covers this Pokémon’s body is dense and springy. Even sharp fangs bounce right off.\nHerdier is a very smart and friendly Pokémon. So much so that there’s a theory that Herdier was the first Pokémon to partner with people.

ThingDef.label: Stoutland
ThingDef.description: Stoutland is immensely proud of its impressive moustache. It’s said that moustache length is what determines social standing among this species.\nThese Pokémon seem to enjoy living with humans. Even a Stoutland caught in the wild will warm up to people in about three days.

ThingDef.label: Purrloin
ThingDef.description: Opponents that get drawn in by its adorable behavior come away with stinging scratches from its claws and stinging pride from its laughter.\nIt steals things from people just to amuse itself with their frustration. A rivalry exists between this Pokémon and Nickit.

ThingDef.label: Liepard
ThingDef.description: This stealthy Pokémon sneaks up behind prey without making any sound at all. It competes with Thievul for territory.\nDon’t be fooled by its gorgeous fur and elegant figure. This is a moody and vicious Pokémon.

ThingDef.label: Pansage
ThingDef.description: It’s good at finding berries and gathers them from all over. It’s kind enough to share them with friends.\nIt shares the leaf on its head with weary-looking Pokémon. These leaves are known to relieve stress.

ThingDef.label: Simisage
ThingDef.description: Ill tempered, it fights by swinging its barbed tail around wildly. The leaf growing on its head is very bitter.\nIt attacks enemies with strikes of its thorn-covered tail. This Pokémon is wild tempered.

ThingDef.label: Pansear
ThingDef.description: This Pokémon lives in caves in volcanoes. The fire within the tuft on its head can reach 600 degrees Fahrenheit.\nVery intelligent, it roasts berries before eating them. It likes to help people.

ThingDef.label: Simisear
ThingDef.description: When it gets excited, embers rise from its head and tail and it gets hot. For some reason, it loves sweets.\nA flame burns inside its body. It scatters embers from its head and tail to sear its opponents.

ThingDef.label: Panpour
ThingDef.description: The water stored inside the tuft on its head is full of nutrients. Plants that receive its water grow large.\nThe water stored inside the tuft on its head is full of nutrients. It waters plants with it using its tail.

ThingDef.label: Simipour
ThingDef.description: It prefers places with clean water. When its tuft runs low, it replenishes it by siphoning up water with its tail.\nThe high-pressure water expelled from its tail is so powerful, it can destroy a concrete wall.

ThingDef.label: Munna
ThingDef.description: It eats dreams and releases mist. The mist is pink when it’s eating a good dream, and black when it’s eating a nightmare.\nLate at night, it appears beside people’s pillows. As it feeds on dreams, the patterns on its body give off a faint glow.

ThingDef.label: Musharna
ThingDef.description: It drowses and dreams all the time. It’s best to leave it be if it’s just woken up, as it’s a terrible grump when freshly roused from sleep.\nWhen dark mists emanate from its body, don’t get too near. If you do, your nightmares will become reality.

ThingDef.label: Pidove
ThingDef.description: It’s forgetful and not very bright, but many Trainers love it anyway for its friendliness and sincerity.\nWhere people go, these Pokémon follow. If you’re scattering food for them, be careful—several hundred of them can gather at once.

ThingDef.label: Tranquill
ThingDef.description: These bright Pokémon have acute memories. Apparently delivery workers often choose them as their partners.\nIt can fly moderately quickly. No matter how far it travels, it can always find its way back to its master and its nest.

ThingDef.label: Unfezant
ThingDef.description: This Pokémon is intelligent and intensely proud. People will sit up and take notice if you become the Trainer of one.\nUnfezant are exceptional fliers. The females are known for their stamina, while the males outclass them in terms of speed.

ThingDef.label: Blitzle
ThingDef.description: Its mane shines when it discharges electricity. They use the frequency and rhythm of these flashes to communicate.\nWhen thunderclouds cover the sky, it will appear. It can catch lightning with its mane and store the electricity.

ThingDef.label: Zebstrika
ThingDef.description: They have lightning-like movements. When Zebstrika run at full speed, the sound of thunder reverberates.\nWhen this ill-tempered Pokémon runs wild, it shoots lightning from its mane in all directions.

ThingDef.label: Roggenrola
ThingDef.description: When it detects a noise, it starts to move. The energy core inside it makes this Pokémon slightly warm to the touch.\nIt’s as hard as steel, but apparently a long soak in water will cause it to soften a bit.

ThingDef.label: Boldore
ThingDef.description: It relies on sound in order to monitor what’s in its vicinity. When angered, it will attack without ever changing the direction it’s facing.\nIf you see its orange crystals start to glow, be wary. It’s about to fire off bursts of energy.

ThingDef.label: Gigalith
ThingDef.description: Although its energy blasts can blow away a dump truck, they have a limitation—they can only be fired when the sun is out.\nThis hardy Pokémon can often be found on construction sites and in mines, working alongside people and Copperajah.

ThingDef.label: Woobat
ThingDef.description: It emits ultrasonic waves as it flutters about, searching for its prey—bug Pokémon.\nWhile inside a cave, if you look up and see lots of heart-shaped marks lining the walls, it’s evidence that Woobat live there.

ThingDef.label: Swoobat
ThingDef.description: The auspicious shape of this Pokémon’s nose apparently led some regions to consider Swoobat a symbol of good luck.\nEmitting powerful sound waves tires it out. Afterward, it won’t be able to fly for a little while.

ThingDef.label: Drilbur
ThingDef.description: It’s a digger, using its claws to burrow through the ground. It causes damage to vegetable crops, so many farmers have little love for it.\nIt brings its claws together and whirls around at high speed before rushing toward its prey.

ThingDef.label: Excadrill
ThingDef.description: Known as the Drill King, this Pokémon can tunnel through the terrain at speeds of over 90 mph.\nIt’s not uncommon for tunnels that appear to have formed naturally to actually be a result of Excadrill’s rampant digging.

ThingDef.label: Audino
ThingDef.description: This Pokémon has a kind heart. By touching with its feelers, Audino can gauge other creatures’ feelings and physical conditions.\nAudino’s sense of hearing is superb. Not even a pebble rolling along over a mile away will escape Audino’s ears.

ThingDef.label: Timburr
ThingDef.description: Timburr that have started carrying logs that are about three times their size are nearly ready to evolve.\nIt loves helping out with construction projects. It loves it so much that if rain causes work to halt, it swings its log around and throws a tantrum.

ThingDef.label: Gurdurr
ThingDef.description: Gurdurr excels at demolition—construction is not its forte. In any case, there’s skill in the way this Pokémon wields its metal beam.\nIt shows off its muscles to Machoke and other Gurdurr. If it fails to measure up to the other Pokémon, it lies low for a little while.

ThingDef.label: Conkeldurr
ThingDef.description: When going all out, this Pokémon throws aside its concrete pillars and leaps at opponents to pummel them with its fists.\nConcrete mixed by Conkeldurr is much more durable than normal concrete, even when the compositions of the two materials are the same.

ThingDef.label: Tympole
ThingDef.description: It uses sound waves to communicate with others of its kind. People and other Pokémon species can’t hear its cries of warning.\nGraceful ripples running across the water’s surface are a sure sign that Tympole are singing in high-pitched voices below.

ThingDef.label: Palpitoad
ThingDef.description: On occasion, their cries are sublimely pleasing to the ear. Palpitoad with larger lumps on their bodies can sing with a wider range of sounds.\nIt weakens its prey with sound waves intense enough to cause headaches, then entangles them with its sticky tongue.

ThingDef.label: Seismitoad
ThingDef.description: This Pokémon is popular among the elderly, who say the vibrations of its lumps are great for massages.\nThe vibrating of the bumps all over its body causes earthquake-like tremors. Seismitoad and Croagunk are similar species.

ThingDef.label: Throh
ThingDef.description: They train in groups of five. Any member that can’t keep up will discard its belt and leave the group.\nIt performs throwing moves with first-rate skill. Over the course of many battles, Throh’s belt grows darker as it absorbs its wearer’s sweat.

ThingDef.label: Sawk
ThingDef.description: The karate chops of a Sawk that’s trained itself to the limit can cleave the ocean itself.\nIf you see a Sawk training in the mountains in its single-minded pursuit of strength, it’s best to quietly pass by.

ThingDef.label: Sewaddle
ThingDef.description: Since this Pokémon makes its own clothes out of leaves, it is a popular mascot for fashion designers.\nThis Pokémon makes clothes for itself. It chews up leaves and sews them with sticky thread extruded from its mouth.

ThingDef.label: Swadloon
ThingDef.description: It protects itself from the cold by wrapping up in leaves. It stays on the move, eating leaves in forests.\nForests where Swadloon live have superb foliage because the nutrients they make from fallen leaves nourish the plant life.

ThingDef.label: Leavanny
ThingDef.description: It keeps its eggs warm with heat from fermenting leaves. It also uses leaves to make warm wrappings for Sewaddle.\nUpon finding a small Pokémon, it weaves clothing for it from leaves by using the sticky silk secreted from its mouth.

ThingDef.label: Venipede
ThingDef.description: Its fangs are highly venomous. If this Pokémon finds prey it thinks it can eat, it leaps for them without any thought of how things might turn out.\nVenipede and Sizzlipede are similar species, but when the two meet, a huge fight ensues.

ThingDef.label: Whirlipede
ThingDef.description: Whirlipede protects itself with a sturdy shell and poisonous spikes while it stores up the energy it’ll need for evolution.\nThis Pokémon spins itself rapidly and charges into its opponents. Its top speed is just over 60 mph.

ThingDef.label: Scolipede
ThingDef.description: Scolipede engage in fierce territorial battles with Centiskorch. At the end of one of these battles, the victor makes a meal of the loser.\nScolipede latches on to its prey with the claws on its neck before slamming them into the ground and jabbing them with its claws’ toxic spikes.

ThingDef.label: Cottonee
ThingDef.description: Weaving together the cotton of both Cottonee and Eldegoss produces exquisite cloth that’s highly prized by many luxury brands.\nIt shoots cotton from its body to protect itself. If it gets caught up in hurricane-strength winds, it can get sent to the other side of the Earth.

ThingDef.label: Whimsicott
ThingDef.description: As long as this Pokémon bathes in sunlight, its cotton keeps growing. If too much cotton fluff builds up, Whimsicott tears it off and scatters it.\nIt scatters cotton all over the place as a prank. If it gets wet, it’ll become too heavy to move and have no choice but to answer for its mischief.

ThingDef.label: Petilil
ThingDef.description: The deeper the color of a Petilil’s leaves, the healthier the Pokémon is. Petilil sometimes makes its home in a well-tended field or flowerbed.\nPetilil appears around sources of clean water. Boiling leaves from this Pokémon’s head results in a liquid that’s sometimes used as a bug repellent.

ThingDef.label: Lilligant
ThingDef.description: Essential oils made from Lilligant flowers have a sublime scent, but they’re also staggeringly expensive.\nIt’s believed that even first-rate gardeners have a hard time getting the flower on a Lilligant’s head to bloom.

ThingDef.label: Basculin
ThingDef.description: In the past, it often appeared on the dinner table. The meat of red-striped Basculin is on the fatty side, and it’s more popular with the youth.\nAnglers love the fight this Pokémon puts up on the hook. And there are always more to catch— many people release them into lakes illicitly.

ThingDef.label: Sandile
ThingDef.description: Sandile is small, but its legs and lower body are powerful. Pushing sand aside as it goes, Sandile moves through the desert as if it’s swimming.\nThe desert gets cold at night, so when the sun sets, this Pokémon burrows deep into the sand and sleeps until sunrise.

ThingDef.label: Krokorok
ThingDef.description: Although this Pokémon has specialized eyes that allow it to see in the dark, Krokorok won’t move much at night—the desert gets cold after sunset.\nKrokorok has specialized eyes that enable it to see in the dark. This ability lets Krokorok hunt in the dead of night without getting lost.

ThingDef.label: Krookodile
ThingDef.description: While terribly aggressive, Krookodile also has the patience to stay hidden under sand for days, lying in wait for prey.\nThis Pokémon is known as the Bully of the Sands. Krookodile’s mighty jaws can bite through heavy plates of iron with almost no effort at all.

ThingDef.label: Darumaka
ThingDef.description: This popular symbol of good fortune will never fall over in its sleep, no matter how it’s pushed or pulled.\nIt derives its power from fire burning inside its body. If the fire dwindles, this Pokémon will immediately fall asleep.

ThingDef.label: Darmanitan
ThingDef.description: This Pokémon’s power level rises along with the temperature of its fire, which can reach 2,500 degrees Fahrenheit.\nThe thick arms of this hot-blooded Pokémon can deliver punches capable of obliterating a dump truck.

ThingDef.label: Maractus
ThingDef.description: Once each year, this Pokémon scatters its seeds. They’re jam-packed with nutrients, making them a precious food source out in the desert.\nWith noises that could be mistaken for the rattles of maracas, it creates an upbeat rhythm, startling bird Pokémon and making them fly off in a hurry.

ThingDef.label: Dwebble
ThingDef.description: It first tries to find a rock to live in, but if there are no suitable rocks to be found, Dwebble may move in to the ports of a Hippowdon.\nWhen it finds a stone appealing, it creates a hole inside it and uses it as its home. This Pokémon is the natural enemy of Roggenrola and Rolycoly.

ThingDef.label: Crustle
ThingDef.description: Its thick claws are its greatest weapons. They’re mighty enough to crack Rhyperior’s carapace.\nThis highly territorial Pokémon prefers dry climates. It won’t come out of its boulder on rainy days.

ThingDef.label: Scraggy
ThingDef.description: It protects itself with its durable skin. It’s thought that this Pokémon will evolve once its skin has completely stretched out.\nIf it locks eyes with you, watch out! Nothing and no one is safe from the reckless headbutts of this troublesome Pokémon.

ThingDef.label: Scrafty
ThingDef.description: While mostly known for having the temperament of an aggressive ruffian, this Pokémon takes very good care of its family, friends, and territory.\nAs halfhearted as this Pokémon’s kicks may seem, they pack enough power to shatter Conkeldurr’s concrete pillars.

ThingDef.label: Sigilyph
ThingDef.description: A discovery was made in the desert where Sigilyph fly. The ruins of what may have been an ancient city were found beneath the sands.\nPsychic power allows these Pokémon to fly. Some say they were the guardians of an ancient city. Others say they were the guardians’ emissaries.

ThingDef.label: Yamask
ThingDef.description: The spirit of a person from a bygone age became this Pokémon. It rambles through ruins, searching for someone who knows its face.\nIt wanders through ruins by night, carrying a mask that’s said to have been the face it had when it was still human.

ThingDef.label: Cofagrigus
ThingDef.description: There are many depictions of Cofagrigus decorating ancient tombs. They’re symbols of the wealth that kings of bygone eras had.\nThis Pokémon has a body of sparkling gold. People say it no longer remembers that it was once human.

ThingDef.label: Tirtouga
ThingDef.description: Tirtouga is considered to be the ancestor of many turtle Pokémon. It was restored to life from a fossil.\nThis Pokémon inhabited ancient seas. Although it can only crawl, it still comes up onto land in search of prey.

ThingDef.label: Carracosta
ThingDef.description: This Pokémon emerges from the water in search of prey despite the fact that it moves more slowly on land.\nCarracosta completely devours its prey—bones, shells, and all. Because of this, Carracosta’s own shell grows thick and sturdy.

ThingDef.label: Archen
ThingDef.description: Archen is said to be the ancestor of bird Pokémon. It lived in treetops, eating berries and bug Pokémon.\nThis Pokémon was successfully restored from a fossil. As research suggested, Archen is unable to fly. But it’s very good at jumping.

ThingDef.label: Archeops
ThingDef.description: Though capable of flight, Archeops was apparently better at hunting on the ground.\nIt needs a running start to take off. If Archeops wants to fly, it first needs to run nearly 25 mph, building speed over a course of about 2.5 miles.

ThingDef.label: Trubbish
ThingDef.description: This Pokémon was born from a bag stuffed with trash. Galarian Weezing relish the fumes belched by Trubbish.\nIts favorite places are unsanitary ones. If you leave trash lying around, you could even find one of these Pokémon living in your room.

ThingDef.label: Garbodor
ThingDef.description: The toxic liquid it launches from its right arm is so virulent that it can kill a weakened creature instantly.\nThis Pokémon eats trash, which turns into poison inside its body. The main component of the poison depends on what sort of trash was eaten.

ThingDef.label: Zorua
ThingDef.description: Zorua sometimes transforms into a person and goes into cities to search for food. When Zorua does this, it usually takes on the form of a child.\nZorua is a timid Pokémon. This disposition seems to be what led to the development of Zorua’s ability to take on the forms of other creatures.

ThingDef.label: Zoroark
ThingDef.description: Seeking to ease the burden of their solitude, lonely Trainers tell Zoroark to show illusions to them.\nThis Pokémon cares deeply about others of its kind, and it will conjure terrifying illusions to keep its den and pack safe.

ThingDef.label: Minccino
ThingDef.description: They pet each other with their tails as a form of greeting. Of the two, the one whose tail is fluffier is a bit more boastful.\nThe way it brushes away grime with its tail can be helpful when cleaning. But its focus on spotlessness can make cleaning more of a hassle.

ThingDef.label: Cinccino
ThingDef.description: A special oil that seeps through their fur helps them avoid attacks. The oil fetches a high price at market.\nIts body secretes oil that this Pokémon spreads over its nest as a coating to protect it from dust. Cinccino won’t tolerate even a speck of the stuff.

ThingDef.label: Gothita
ThingDef.description: Even when nobody seems to be around, Gothita can still be heard making a muted cry. Many believe it’s speaking to something only it can see.\nThough they’re still only babies, there’s psychic power stored in their ribbonlike feelers, and sometimes they use that power to fight.

ThingDef.label: Gothorita
ThingDef.description: On nights when the stars shine, this Pokémon’s psychic power is at its strongest. It’s unknown just what link Gothorita has to the greater universe.\nIt’s said that when stars shine in the night sky, this Pokémon will spirit away sleeping children. Some call it the Witch of Punishment.

ThingDef.label: Gothitelle
ThingDef.description: A criminal who was shown his fate by a Gothitelle went missing that same day and was never seen again.\nIt has tremendous psychic power, but it dislikes conflict. It’s also able to predict the future based on the movement of the stars.

ThingDef.label: Solosis
ThingDef.description: Many say that the special liquid covering this Pokémon’s body would allow it to survive in the vacuum of space.\nIt communicates with others telepathically. Its body is encapsulated in liquid, but if it takes a heavy blow, the liquid will leak out.

ThingDef.label: Duosion
ThingDef.description: Its brain has split into two, and the two halves rarely think alike. Its actions are utterly unpredictable.\nIts psychic power can supposedly cover a range of more than half a mile—but only if its two brains can agree with each other.

ThingDef.label: Reuniclus
ThingDef.description: It’s said that drinking the liquid surrounding Reuniclus grants wisdom. Problem is, the liquid is highly toxic to anything besides Reuniclus itself.\nWhile it could use its psychic abilities in battle, this Pokémon prefers to swing its powerful arms around to beat opponents into submission.

ThingDef.label: Ducklett
ThingDef.description: They are better at swimming than flying, and they happily eat their favorite food, peat moss, as they dive underwater.\nWhen attacked, it uses its feathers to splash water, escaping under cover of the spray.

ThingDef.label: Swanna
ThingDef.description: Swanna start to dance at dusk. The one dancing in the middle is the leader of the flock.\nDespite their elegant appearance, they can flap their wings strongly and fly for thousands of miles.

ThingDef.label: Vanillite
ThingDef.description: Supposedly, this Pokémon was born from an icicle. It spews out freezing air at −58 degrees Fahrenheit to make itself more comfortable.\nUnable to survive in hot areas, it makes itself comfortable by breathing out air cold enough to cause snow. It burrows into the snow to sleep.

ThingDef.label: Vanillish
ThingDef.description: It blasts enemies with cold air reaching −148 degrees Fahrenheit, freezing them solid. But it spares their lives afterward—it’s a kind Pokémon.\nBy drinking pure water, it grows its icy body. This Pokémon can be hard to find on days with warm, sunny weather.

ThingDef.label: Vanilluxe
ThingDef.description: People believe this Pokémon formed when two Vanillish stuck together. Its body temperature is roughly 21 degrees Fahrenheit.\nWhen its anger reaches a breaking point, this Pokémon unleashes a fierce blizzard that freezes every creature around it, be they friend or foe.

ThingDef.label: Deerling
ThingDef.description: The turning of the seasons changes the color and scent of this Pokémon’s fur. People use it to mark the seasons.\nTheir coloring changes according to the seasons and can be slightly affected by the temperature and humidity as well.

ThingDef.label: Sawsbuck
ThingDef.description: They migrate according to the seasons, so some people call Sawsbuck the harbingers of spring.\nThey migrate according to the seasons. People can tell the season by looking at Sawsbuck’s horns.

ThingDef.label: Emolga
ThingDef.description: This Pokémon absolutely loves sweet berries. Sometimes it stuffs its cheeks full of so much food that it can’t fly properly.\nAs Emolga flutters through the air, it crackles with electricity. This Pokémon is cute, but it can cause a lot of trouble.

ThingDef.label: Karrablast
ThingDef.description: It spits a liquid from its mouth to melt through Shelmet’s shell. Karrablast doesn’t eat the shell— it eats only the contents.\nIts strange physiology reacts to electrical energy in interesting ways. The presence of a Shelmet will cause this Pokémon to evolve.

ThingDef.label: Escavalier
ThingDef.description: It charges its enemies, lances at the ready. An image of one of its duels is captured in a famous painting of Escavalier clashing with Sirfetch’d.\nThey use shells they’ve stolen from Shelmet to arm and protect themselves. They’re very popular Pokémon in the Galar region.

ThingDef.label: Foongus
ThingDef.description: The spores released from this Pokémon’s hands are highly poisonous, but when thoroughly dried, the spores can be used as stomach medicine.\nNo one knows what the Poké Ball–like pattern on Foongus means or why Foongus has it.

ThingDef.label: Amoonguss
ThingDef.description: Amoonguss generally doesn’t move much. It tends to stand still near Poké Balls that have been dropped on the ground.\nThis Pokémon puffs poisonous spores at its foes. If the spores aren’t washed off quickly, they’ll grow into mushrooms wherever they land.

ThingDef.label: Frillish
ThingDef.description: Legend has it that the residents of a sunken ancient city changed into these Pokémon.\nIt envelops its prey in its veillike arms and draws it down to the deeps, five miles below the ocean’s surface.

ThingDef.label: Jellicent
ThingDef.description: Whenever a full moon hangs in the night sky, schools of Jellicent gather near the surface of the sea, waiting for their prey to appear.\nMost of this Pokémon’s body composition is identical to sea water. It makes sunken ships its lair.

ThingDef.label: Alomomola
ThingDef.description: The reason it helps Pokémon in a weakened condition is that any Pokémon coming after them may also attack Alomomola.\nFishermen take them along on long voyages, because if you have an Alomomola with you, there’ll be no need for a doctor or medicine.

ThingDef.label: Joltik
ThingDef.description: Joltik latch on to other Pokémon and suck out static electricity. They’re often found sticking to Yamper’s hindquarters.\nJoltik can be found clinging to other Pokémon. It’s soaking up static electricity because it can’t produce a charge on its own.

ThingDef.label: Galvantula
ThingDef.description: It lays traps of electrified threads near the nests of bird Pokémon, aiming to snare chicks that are not yet good at flying.\nIt launches electrified fur from its abdomen as its means of attack. Opponents hit by the fur could be in for three full days and nights of paralysis.

ThingDef.label: Ferroseed
ThingDef.description: Mossy caves are their preferred dwellings. Enzymes contained in mosses help Ferroseed’s spikes grow big and strong.\nIt defends itself by launching spikes, but its aim isn’t very good at first. Only after a lot of practice will it improve.

ThingDef.label: Ferrothorn
ThingDef.description: Its spikes are harder than steel. This Pokémon crawls across rock walls by stabbing the spikes on its feelers into the stone.\nThis Pokémon scrapes its spikes across rocks, and then uses the tips of its feelers to absorb the nutrients it finds within the stone.

ThingDef.label: Klink
ThingDef.description: It’s suspected that Klink were the inspiration behind ancient people’s invention of the first gears.\nThe two minigears that compose this Pokémon are closer than twins. They mesh well only with each other.

ThingDef.label: Klang
ThingDef.description: Many companies in the Galar region choose Klang as their logo. This Pokémon is considered the symbol of industrial technology.\nWhen Klang goes all out, the minigear links up perfectly with the outer part of the big gear, and this Pokémon’s rotation speed increases sharply.

ThingDef.label: Klinklang
ThingDef.description: The three gears that compose this Pokémon spin at high speed. Its new spiked gear isn’t a living creature.\nFrom its spikes, it launches powerful blasts of electricity. Its red core contains an enormous amount of energy.

ThingDef.label: Tynamo
ThingDef.description: One alone can emit only a trickle of electricity, so a group of them gathers to unleash a powerful electric shock.\nWhile one alone doesn’t have much power, a chain of many Tynamo can be as powerful as lightning.

ThingDef.label: Eelektrik
ThingDef.description: These Pokémon have a big appetite. When they spot their prey, they attack it and paralyze it with electricity.\nIt wraps itself around its prey and paralyzes it with electricity from the round spots on its sides. Then it chomps.

ThingDef.label: Eelektross
ThingDef.description: They crawl out of the ocean using their arms. They will attack prey on shore and immediately drag it into the ocean.\nWith their sucker mouths, they suck in prey. Then they use their fangs to shock the prey with electricity.

ThingDef.label: Elgyem
ThingDef.description: This Pokémon was discovered about 50 years ago. Its highly developed brain enables it to exert its psychic powers.\nIf this Pokémon stands near a TV, strange scenery will appear on the screen. That scenery is said to be from its home.

ThingDef.label: Beheeyem
ThingDef.description: Sometimes found drifting above wheat fields, this Pokémon can control the memories of its opponents.\nWhenever a Beheeyem visits a farm, a Dubwool mysteriously disappears.

ThingDef.label: Litwick
ThingDef.description: The younger the life this Pokémon absorbs, the brighter and eerier the flame on its head burns.\nThe flame on its head keeps its body slightly warm. This Pokémon takes lost children by the hand to guide them to the spirit world.

ThingDef.label: Lampent
ThingDef.description: It lurks in cities, pretending to be a lamp. Once it finds someone whose death is near, it will trail quietly after them.\nThis Pokémon appears just before someone passes away, so it’s feared as an emissary of death.

ThingDef.label: Chandelure
ThingDef.description: In homes illuminated by Chandelure instead of lights, funerals were a constant occurrence— or so it’s said.\nThis Pokémon haunts dilapidated mansions. It sways its arms to hypnotize opponents with the ominous dancing of its flames.

ThingDef.label: Axew
ThingDef.description: They play with each other by knocking their large tusks together. Their tusks break sometimes, but they grow back so quickly that it isn’t a concern.\nThese Pokémon nest in the ground and use their tusks to crush hard berries. Crushing berries is also how they test each other’s strength.

ThingDef.label: Fraxure
ThingDef.description: Its skin is as hard as a suit of armor. Fraxure’s favorite strategy is to tackle its opponents, stabbing them with its tusks at the same time.\nAfter battle, this Pokémon carefully sharpens its tusks on river rocks. It needs to take care of its tusks—if one breaks, it will never grow back.

ThingDef.label: Haxorus
ThingDef.description: While usually kindhearted, it can be terrifying if angered. Tusks that can slice through steel beams are how Haxorus deals with its adversaries.\nIts resilient tusks are its pride and joy. It licks up dirt to take in the minerals it needs to keep its tusks in top condition.

ThingDef.label: Cubchoo
ThingDef.description: It sniffles before performing a move, using its frosty snot to provide an icy element to any move that needs it.\nWhen this Pokémon is in good health, its snot becomes thicker and stickier. It will smear its snot on anyone it doesn’t like.

ThingDef.label: Beartic
ThingDef.description: It swims energetically through frigid seas. When it gets tired, it freezes the seawater with its breath so it can rest on the ice.\nIt swims through frigid seas, searching for prey. From its frozen breath, it forms icy fangs that are harder than steel.

ThingDef.label: Cryogonal
ThingDef.description: When the weather gets hot, these Pokémon turn into water vapor. Cryogonal are almost never seen during summer.\nWith its icy chains, Cryogonal freezes those it encounters. It then takes its victims away to somewhere unknown.

ThingDef.label: Shelmet
ThingDef.description: It has a strange physiology that responds to electricity. When together with Karrablast, Shelmet evolves for some reason.\nWhen attacked, it tightly shuts the lid of its shell. This reaction fails to protect it from Karrablast, however, because they can still get into the shell.

ThingDef.label: Accelgor
ThingDef.description: Discarding its shell made it nimble. To keep itself from dehydrating, it wraps its body in bands of membrane.\nIt moves with blinding speed and lobs poison at foes. Featuring Accelgor as a main character is a surefire way to make a movie or comic popular.

ThingDef.label: Stunfisk
ThingDef.description: For some reason, this Pokémon smiles slightly when it emits a strong electric current from the yellow markings on its body.\nThanks to bacteria that lived in the mud flats with it, this Pokémon developed the organs it uses to generate electricity.

ThingDef.label: Mienfoo
ThingDef.description: Though small, Mienfoo’s temperament is fierce. Any creature that approaches Mienfoo carelessly will be greeted with a flurry of graceful attacks.\nIn one minute, a well-trained Mienfoo can chop with its arms more than 100 times.

ThingDef.label: Mienshao
ThingDef.description: Delivered at blinding speeds, kicks from this Pokémon can shatter massive boulders into tiny pieces.\nWhen Mienshao comes across a truly challenging opponent, it will lighten itself by biting off the fur on its arms.

ThingDef.label: Druddigon
ThingDef.description: Druddigon are vicious and cunning. They take up residence in nests dug out by other Pokémon, treating the stolen nests as their own lairs.\nDruddigon lives in caves, but it never skips sunbathing—it won’t be able to move if its body gets too cold.

ThingDef.label: Golett
ThingDef.description: This Pokémon was created from clay. It received orders from its master many thousands of years ago, and it still follows those orders to this day.\nThey were sculpted from clay in ancient times. No one knows why, but some of them are driven to continually line up boulders.

ThingDef.label: Golurk
ThingDef.description: There’s a theory that inside Golurk is a perpetual motion machine that produces limitless energy, but this belief hasn’t been proven.\nArtillery platforms built into the walls of ancient castles served as perches from which Golurk could fire energy beams.

ThingDef.label: Pawniard
ThingDef.description: A pack of these Pokémon forms to serve a Bisharp boss. Each Pawniard trains diligently, dreaming of one day taking the lead.\nIt uses river stones to maintain the cutting edges of the blades covering its body. These sharpened blades allow it to bring down opponents.

ThingDef.label: Bisharp
ThingDef.description: Violent conflicts erupt between Bisharp and Fraxure over places where sharpening stones can be found.\nIt’s accompanied by a large retinue of Pawniard. Bisharp keeps a keen eye on its minions, ensuring none of them even think of double-crossing it.

ThingDef.label: Bouffalant
ThingDef.description: These Pokémon live in herds of about 20 individuals. Bouffalant that betray the herd will lose the hair on their heads for some reason.\nThese Pokémon can crush a car with no more than a headbutt. Bouffalant with more hair on their heads hold higher positions within the herd.

ThingDef.label: Rufflet
ThingDef.description: A combative Pokémon, it’s ready to pick a fight with anyone. It has talons that can crush hard berries.\nIf it spies a strong Pokémon, Rufflet can’t resist challenging it to a battle. But if Rufflet loses, it starts bawling.

ThingDef.label: Braviary
ThingDef.description: Because this Pokémon is hotheaded and belligerent, it’s Corviknight that’s taken the role of transportation in Galar.\nKnown for its bravery and pride, this majestic Pokémon is often seen as a motif for various kinds of emblems.

ThingDef.label: Vullaby
ThingDef.description: Vullaby grow quickly. Bones that have gotten too small for older Vullaby to wear often get passed down to younger ones in the nest.\nIt wears a bone to protect its rear. It often squabbles with others of its kind over particularly comfy bones.

ThingDef.label: Mandibuzz
ThingDef.description: They adorn themselves with bones. There seem to be fashion trends among them, as different bones come into and fall out of popularity.\nAlthough it’s a bit of a ruffian, this Pokémon will take lost Vullaby under its wing and care for them till they’re ready to leave the nest.

ThingDef.label: Heatmor
ThingDef.description: A flame serves as its tongue, melting through the hard shell of Durant so that Heatmor can devour their insides.\nThere’s a hole in its tail that allows it to draw in the air it needs to keep its fire burning. If the hole gets blocked, this Pokémon will fall ill.

ThingDef.label: Durant
ThingDef.description: With their large mandibles, these Pokémon can crunch their way through rock. They work together to protect their eggs from Sandaconda.\nThey lay their eggs deep inside their nests. When attacked by Heatmor, they retaliate using their massive mandibles.

ThingDef.label: Deino
ThingDef.description: Because it can’t see, this Pokémon is constantly biting at everything it touches, trying to keep track of its surroundings.\nWhen it encounters something, its first urge is usually to bite it. If it likes what it tastes, it will commit the associated scent to memory.

ThingDef.label: Zweilous
ThingDef.description: Their two heads will fight each other over a single piece of food. Zweilous are covered in scars even without battling others.\nWhile hunting for prey, Zweilous wanders its territory, its two heads often bickering over which way to go.

ThingDef.label: Hydreigon
ThingDef.description: The three heads take turns sinking their teeth into the opponent. Their attacks won’t slow until their target goes down.\nThere are a slew of stories about villages that were destroyed by Hydreigon. It bites anything that moves.

ThingDef.label: Larvesta
ThingDef.description: Larvesta’s body is warm all over. It spouts fire from the tips of its horns to intimidate predators and scare prey.\nThe people of ancient times believed that Larvesta fell from the sun.

ThingDef.label: Volcarona
ThingDef.description: This Pokémon emerges from a cocoon formed of raging flames. Ancient murals depict Volcarona as a deity of fire.\nVolcarona scatters burning scales. Some say it does this to start fires. Others say it’s trying to rescue those that suffer in the cold.

ThingDef.label: Cobalion
ThingDef.description: From the moment it’s born, this Pokémon radiates the air of a leader. Its presence will calm even vicious foes.\nThis Pokémon appears in a legend alongside Terrakion and Virizion, fighting against humans in defense of the Unova region’s Pokémon.

ThingDef.label: Terrakion
ThingDef.description: In Unovan legend, Terrakion battled against humans in an effort to protect other Pokémon.\nIt has phenomenal power. It will mercilessly crush anyone or anything that bullies small Pokémon.

ThingDef.label: Virizion
ThingDef.description: It darts around opponents with a flurry of quick movements, slicing them up with its horns.\nA legend tells of this Pokémon working together with Cobalion and Terrakion to protect the Pokémon of the Unova region.

ThingDef.label: Tornadus
ThingDef.description: Tornadus expels massive energy from its tail, causing severe storms. Its power is great enough to blow houses away.\nThe lower half of its body is wrapped in a cloud of energy. It zooms through the sky at 200 mph.

ThingDef.label: Thundurus
ThingDef.description: As it flies around, it shoots lightning all over the place and causes forest fires. It is therefore disliked.\nThe spikes on its tail discharge immense bolts of lightning. It flies around the Unova region firing off lightning bolts.

ThingDef.label: Reshiram
ThingDef.description: When Reshiram’s tail flares, the heat energy moves the atmosphere and changes the world’s weather.\nThis legendary Pokémon can scorch the world with fire. It helps those who want to build a world of truth.

ThingDef.label: Zekrom
ThingDef.description: Concealing itself in lightning clouds, it flies throughout the Unova region. It creates electricity in its tail.\nThis legendary Pokémon can scorch the world with lightning. It assists those who want to build an ideal world.

ThingDef.label: Landorus
ThingDef.description: From the forces of lightning and wind, it creates energy to give nutrients to the soil and make the land abundant.\nLands visited by Landorus grant such bountiful crops that it has been hailed as “The Guardian of the Fields.”

ThingDef.label: Kyurem
ThingDef.description: It generates a powerful, freezing energy inside itself, but its body became frozen when the energy leaked out.\nThis legendary ice Pokémon waits for a hero to fill in the missing parts of its body with truth or ideals.

ThingDef.label: Keldeo
ThingDef.description: When it is resolute, its body fills with power and it becomes swifter. Its jumps are then too fast to follow.\nIt crosses the world, running over the surfaces of oceans and rivers. It appears at scenic waterfronts.

ThingDef.label: Meloetta
ThingDef.description: Its melodies are sung with a special vocalization method that can control the feelings of those who hear it.\nThe melodies sung by Meloetta have the power to make Pokémon that hear them happy or sad.

ThingDef.label: Genesect
ThingDef.description: This Pokémon existed 300 million years ago. Team Plasma altered it and attached a cannon to its back.\nThis ancient bug Pokémon was altered by Team Plasma. They upgraded the cannon on its back.
